body: @tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments.

AppVeyor has a failure of the new test: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1236-master/job/709ihjeijd26hn4t/tests

It expected to get 3 failed evaluators (two mappers and one update), but got only 2. Is our check still too strict?
Yes, the last one is in Dispose. Driver may shut down before receiving it. I just relaxed the checking little bit.

I've modified the test to be inherited from `TestFailMapperEvaluators`: https://github.com/apache/reef/compare/master...tcNickolas:PR-1205. I didn't run into any issues. As a guess, the problem might've been the test name - the name of the child test in the new class must be the same as in the parent, otherwise it won't be an override.
I'll merge this. It would be great if the next pull request showed an actual usage of metrics collections, as some methods' purpose (like `ParentCollector`) is not quite clear to me yet.
Does .NET offer a temp file creation scheme where the files get deleted on process exit? If so, that would be a clean way to rid ourselves of the responsibility to delete the files :)
@tcNickolas  Please have a look at this PR.

No, it doesn't look like there is such a thing in .NET. A quick search offers `GetTempFileName()` to simplify creation of temp file but one needs custom code to dispose of it (for example, by implementing `IDisposable`). We could create a class to manage our temp files uniformly, as suggested in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1468853/temporary-files-in-net, but probably not in this change.
Test updated.
I completed a  pass.
There are two AppVeyor failures. But they are unrelated to this change. I will test and merge.
LGTM. I'll clean up some empty tags in files touched by this change, test and merge

It looks like the metrics system introduced in this series of pull requests is so far not used to collect any metrics in actual REEF code. Can you provide an example of how it should be used to collect actual metrics and pass them to driver?
@tcNickolas The example you requested is going to be the next PR next week. I will address rest of comments later today.
@tcNickolas I have addressed your comments. Please have a look.

AppVeyor test is stuck for some reason, so I ran tests locally. Out of 10-15 runs one test failed twice:

    Org.Apache.REEF.Common.Tests.Metrics.MetricsSystemTests.TestPubishMetricsNow
    Did not receive expected number of records.\r\nExpected: False\r\nActual:   True

Does it have some race condition which sometimes causes test failure? Please take a look
please do not review. I migrating between machines, and have pushed the changes here for durability.
@dkm2110 Do you have ideas about the causes of test failure?
LGTM. I will test and merge.

We can notice that before this change AppVeyor ran 748 tests (https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1244-master), and with this change it runs 730 tests (https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/460-REEF-1690). The difference is exactly 18 tests which have trait Environment set: previously they were attempted by our test goal but skipped by xUnit, and now they are not even attempted. This is expected
LGTM. There is one AppVeyor failure but looks irrelevant to the change. I will test and merge.
@tcNickolas  Starting looking at it again now.

@tcNickolas It is weird..Test always passes if I run it individually but fails like you mentioned when I run the whole Common.Tests.... So I am confused what might be happening... Anyways I am still trying to debug.

Maybe it is sharing some state with other tests from Common.Tests? Have you tried running `MetricsSystemTests` tests separately (you can do it both from VS and from command line by using appropriate filters)?

The new test fails in two of four AppVeyor runs done for this pull request: [1](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1248-master/job/j0b5vs85pyd5r128/tests) [2](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/jwang98052/reef/build/job/arlwcvmxrrda6p6e/tests)

Please stabilize the test
I completed a pass.
@tcNickolas  I ran MetricsSystemTests also.. It still fails.....There is no explicit state sharing that happens between the tests. So I am confused about this.

@dkm2110 Any progress on this? There might be some implicit state sharing. We have lots of tests which, for example, send messages and read messages sent from another test (like in #1208) even though they are not supposed to do this.
@tcNickolas No not yet.....still looking..... this one is turning out to be tricky. There is no network etc. involved here..... so not sure where is the sharing happening.
@tcNickolas I have not been able to find the source of state sharing..... Can you take this over and I can help you with any questions in coming days. Thanks.
@dkm2110 I'll see what I can do. Meanwhile, please send the pull request which is supposed to follow this one (the actual use of the metrics system)
AppVeyor failures are not related to the change, since it only touches one file. A good build is at https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/463-REEF-1693
@dkm2110 Please let us know whether you'll be sending one more pull request. Without the example of how these metrics utilities are supposed to be used it's fairly hard to actually use this work.
LGTM. There are two test failures in appveyor tests. Apparently they are not related to this change. I will test and merge.
LGTM. I will test and merge.
LGTM. I will test and merge.

@motus I've merged it, but unfortunately the commit does not close this PR because in the commit message the PR number does not follow *closes* directly (i.e., `Closes PR #PR_ID`).

Could you close this PR manually? Thanks!
@yunseong will do. Thanks for reviewing!
LGTM and HelloREEFYarn runs fine in a YARN cluster. I'll merge it.
@motus Looks good overall. I've left some minor comments. Could you take a look? Thanks!
LGTM and tests passed. Failures in AppVeyor are obviously irrelevant to this change. I'll merge it.
LGTM. I'm merging it.
Looks good and tests passed. I'm merging it.

I've merged this PR, but I made a typo in the commit message by mistake. 
@motus Could you close the PR manually? Sorry for the inconvenience.
Done! Thanks for reviewing @yunseong !
LGTM and tests passed. Failures in AppVeyor are obviously irrelevant to this change. I'll merge it.

The change looks good to me. However, when I try to merge it, I get git error

    fatal: empty ident name (for <shouyi@desktop-qpt8urd.redmond.corp.microsoft.com>) not allowed
    Could not commit staged changes.

Looks like git can't get your identity from your commit information. Did you perform the `git config` steps from https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing ?

I checked commit history in your pull request, and indeed the first two commits don't have an author. I think you should try to rebase your branch with the latest master and squash all four commits in this branch into one. If you get the same error, you can try to fix author info for the problematic commits, something like http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3042437/change-commit-author-at-one-specific-commit

If that doesn't work, you can create a new branch and copy the change there, and send a new pull request with proper author info - this might be faster than amending commits history :-)
Judging from the names, these tests are supposed to run on Yarn. Is this correct? Have you tested this change on Yarn? Travis only runs local tests :-(
@yunseong I've made the changes - could you please take another look? Thank you!
@tcNickolas thanks for reviewing! I've updated the assertion messages. As for the YARN tests, these specific tests do not require access to the actual cluster and should pass on our CI servers.
@motus Looks great. I'll merge it if tests pass. Thanks!
Looks good to me. There are several minor comments on code (like indentation - I don't know why StyleCop doesn't catch it), I'll fix them and merge

Actually, I've just tried running the new test locally, and it fails 50% of the time with the same error - it expects 32 running tasks but gets only 31. Please make it more stable, I really don't want to add another transiently failing test to our collection.
LGTM. I will test and merge.

I'm assuming this is new instance of #1212 ? This change looks better, the authorship information is correct.

I've just noticed that step 5 of new instructions recommends to use Maven to build REEF.NET. We use Maven to build Java and msbuild to build .NET (which internally calls Maven but user doesn't need to). Please fix this

This change has been merged (1396fb3dc7a4b9c739e245d260320eb0d3096357) but the pull request is still open. I suspect "Closes PR #" is a wrong magic phrase to close PR automatically, probably has to be just "Closes #".

@motus Please close this PR
Looks good to me. I ran the new test multiple times locally without any failure, and it succeeds in all 4 AppVeyor runs done for this change. I'll clean up empty tags and merge.

The description of the change says the new test is not executed in our test suite, but Travis CI reports that it was executed (https://travis-ci.org/apache/reef/jobs/191183946, look for `UnmanagedAmTest`). Which one is correct?

@tcNickolas both are right :smile: By default, when the `$REEF_TEST_YARN` environment variable is not set, the test always succeeds, and this is what you see on Travis. In order to actually run the test (and make it fail), you need to set this variable to `true`. This way, we still pass all the CI tests, but have a way to check whether Hadoop has fixed the feature that we will eventually need for the Unmanaged AM.
Thanks for reviewing @tcNickolas ! I'll close it now.
In this case I think it's better to use `Assume.assumeTrue(isYarn);`, so that if the environment is not Yarn (and the test is effectively useless), the test is marked not as succeeded but as skipped.
@tcNickolas very good point! I've added a call to `Assume.assumeTrue()`. Thanks for reviewing!

I've verified that the test is skipped on local runtime:

    Running org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.unmanaged.UnmanagedAmTest
    Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 1, Time elapsed: 0.049 sec - in org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.unmanaged.UnmanagedAmTest

Will test and merge

A small note for future: we have a template for commit messages to use at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing. We agreed to make all commit messages uniform, so following the template in the commit from which you create the pull request makes things easier for the reviewer :-) No need to fix this in this pull request, I'll edit the commit message during the merge.
LGTM. I will test and merge.
LGTM. I will test and merge it.
Do you have test case for it?

@jwang98052 I am not sure how to test such functionality. An application ID is assigned by an external component (e.g. a YARN RM), and can be an arbitrary string. There is no way for us to know the value before we receive it from the RM, so there's nothing we can compare it to. The only thing I can check in the unit test is whether the application ID is null or an empty string, but I am not sure it's a meaningful test.
I don't like this. It adds a synchronous step to the job submission. Those apps that need to know can instead bind a handler to `ClientConfiguration.ON_JOB_RUNNING`. Or am I missing something?
I'll test this a few times locally.

after running the tests on Windows 10, I have 28 java processes left running:

```
reef [PR-1232]> get-process java | measure

Count    : 29
```

It is true when we get ApplicationId,, neither means the submit is successful, nor means driver is started. What we did for .Net is to waiting for DriverUrl to be written. The DirverUrl is written in Java.
I ran the same thing in `master`, and have zero java processes left over. So, I think the change isn't complete.
Maybe we need a new event in the Java client? For example `ON_JOB_SUBMITTED`?

@markusweimer thanks for testing it! Looks like we need more cleanup in the evaluators. I'll try to reproduce it on my PC, but for now I'll close this PR and open another one that has only thread logging and cleanup parts.

@markusweimer I guess it depends on the runtime. In YARN, we obtain application ID in a synchronous way, before we even submit the application. Although in general, I agree that returning a value from  `.submit()` is a bit against the spirit of our asynchronous API. I think I'll close this PR for now and issue another (or reopen this one) when I have a better solution.
LGTM. I'll test and merge it. Thanks!

> @motus Do you have some logs to show running
> threads which need to be closed by closing job submission handler? The
> change looks good to me but I'm not familiar with Java threading in REEF
> enough to predict the behavior change caused by this.

I will try to reproduce it. It seems to be a sporadic event in certain runtimes (e.g. in local mode; for YARN the submission handler does not require any cleanup).
@tcNickolas Thanks for pointing it out! @motus I'll wait a few hours before merging it :)
LGTM, will merge

I'm unsure about the deployment process for the site though. Please verify
Thanks! 😄
@wonook Thanks for the fix! I've checked that all the links point to the right place. I'll try to publish the website with the changes.

@yunseong Please merge this pull request first before publishing the website. We only publish website from our master branch to make sure that our website might be lagging behind master but not the other way around.
@tcNickolas Thanks a lot for reminding me! I'll merge this PR first.

LGTM, but we have to test it by publishing website. I've observed one minor error in our tutorial (https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=56066242):  we renamed `HttpServerShellCmdtHandler` to remove typo (Cmdt), but the website has old one. We can fix this inconsistency and see the API docs aren't removed with this PR.

Then would the following plan work?
1) merge this PR
2) create & merge the PR that fixes the class name
3) publish the website with the changes from 2.

@tcNickolas How do you think?

@yunseong I'm not sure which page of the website you're referring to, since REEF tutorial points to cwiki page which is edited via different means. Any occurrences of `HttpServerShellCmdtHandler` that Google can find within reef.apache.org are in apidocs which we can't update.

Overall the plan looks good. If we don't see a site fix that can be done right now, we can just merge this PR and keep in mind that we need to keep an eye on apidocs during our next publish. It's possible that this fix doesn't resolve all problems, since I recall at some point Java apidocs were also deleted by publishing site.

@tcNickolas Thanks for the confirmation! You're right. The tutorial that I mentioned is not on the website we can update.

Let's merge this PR and see the problem go away at the next time. I'll also keep an eye on the .Net apidocs.


Normal behavior is to have only the `main` thread running at the end of the client process.

@motus Thanks for the result, and additional PR for reproducing this issue. 

When I ran HelloREEF with this PR and #1239 merged, I got the following result:
```
2017-01-25 09:49:04,215 FINE reef.util.ThreadLogger.logThreads main | Threads running at the end of HelloREEF:
	TG main THREAD globalEventExecutor-1-6 :: TIMED_WAITING, Alive, NOT interrupted, NOT daemon
		sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
		java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.parkNanos(LockSupport.java:215)
		java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.awaitNanos(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2078)
		java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue.poll(LinkedBlockingQueue.java:467)
		io.netty.util.concurrent.GlobalEventExecutor.takeTask(GlobalEventExecutor.java:90)
		io.netty.util.concurrent.GlobalEventExecutor$TaskRunner.run(GlobalEventExecutor.java:334)
		io.netty.util.concurrent.DefaultThreadFactory$DefaultRunnableDecorator.run(DefaultThreadFactory.java:137)
		java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
	TG main THREAD main :: RUNNABLE, Alive, NOT interrupted, NOT daemon
		java.lang.Thread.dumpThreads(Native Method)
		java.lang.Thread.getAllStackTraces(Thread.java:1603)
		org.apache.reef.util.ThreadLogger.getFormattedThreadList(ThreadLogger.java:79)
		org.apache.reef.util.ThreadLogger.logThreads(ThreadLogger.java:62)
		org.apache.reef.util.ThreadLogger.logThreads(ThreadLogger.java:45)
		org.apache.reef.examples.hello.HelloREEF.main(HelloREEF.java:70)
	TG main THREAD pool-1-thread-1 :: WAITING, Alive, NOT interrupted, NOT daemon
		java.lang.Object.wait(Native Method)
		java.lang.Object.wait(Object.java:502)
		java.lang.UNIXProcess.waitFor(UNIXProcess.java:396)
		org.apache.reef.runtime.local.process.RunnableProcess.run(RunnableProcess.java:213)
		java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511)
		java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
		java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
		java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
		java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```
I have two questions:
1. The first thread appears intermittently. Maybe the thread is from the Netty, which shuts down gracefully?
2. Is it a normal behavior to have the last entry (`TG main THREAD pool-1-thread-1 :: WAITING, Alive, NOT interrupted, NOT daemon`)? I'd like to confirm that your result does not show one.

@yunseong yes, `globalEventExecutor-1-6` is an internal Wake/Netty thread; it's OK to exit when this thread still exists and is in `TIMED_WAIT` state.

Another thread `pool-1-thread-1` I don't like. I made an effort in my previous pull requests to give more meaningful names to our threads so we can tell where exactly we've started them. I will check why this thread still has an old name and fix it in subsequent PRs.

Also, @yunseong could you please tell me if your HelloREEF client had exited normally or it just hung after dumping the thread info? A non-daemon thread in `WAITING` mode would prevent Java process from exiting, so if your process exits fine, then everything is OK, and the thread showing up in the logs is just a timing issue that we can safely ignore.

If your process blocks on exit because of this thread - we have an issue. Please check that [REEF-1715](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1715) is **not** merged in to make sure that the client is not waiting on the Driver - it looks like that `pool-1-thread-1` thread is actually waiting for the Driver process to finish.

LGTM. I think we should close jobSubmissionHandler in any case. 
@yunseong is it Ok for the merge?
@motus The client always finished successfully. I'll merge this PR  as it works as expected.

This change also cleans up several tests which I've looked at while adding a new one. 

A good AppVeyor build (for at least one job) can be found at https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/484-REEF-1438
I left a question over on JIRA.

Two out of three Travis builds failed test with error

    FailTaskTest.testFailTaskStop:86->failOn:52 Unexpected error: java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException: Task java.util.concurrent.FutureTask@522fca87 rejected from java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor@3f998f38[Terminated, pool size = 0, active threads = 0, queued tasks = 0, completed tasks = 8]

I don't recall seeing this failure previously. Could it be caused by this change?
@tcNickolas hmm, let me double check. Meanwhile, I'll submit logging fixes as a separate PR.
I've moved all logging improvements into a separate PR #1244 (issue [REEF-1728](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1728) in JIRA). Meanwhile, I'll keep testing the shutdown issue on my PC.

Looks like there is an issue indeed, the job https://travis-ci.org/apache/reef/jobs/195674612 fails with the same error.

There's one more potential issue which might be related to your recent work on closing things properly. In Travis, 3 recent builds timed out (because one of individual build jobs took 50 minutes which is the limit for us), while previously they never did. I think this might be related to some thread not closed properly. The problematic builds are marked with `!` in https://travis-ci.org/apache/reef/pull_requests
One of Travis jobs timed out, but since we've seen this in previous jobs as well I don't think it was caused by this change. LGTM, will test locally and merge
